statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Oregon 63, California 58
article.story: EUGENE, Ore. (AP) -- Oregon's postseason opportunities were pretty slim heading into Thursday's game with California. But Aaron Brooks may have saved them with a pair of free throws. Brooks, who finished with nine points, went to the line with 1:14 remaining and calmly converted two attempts to put the Ducks ahead 58-56, and Oregon held on to defeat the Golden Bears 63-58. Bryce Taylor added 15 points for Oregon (13-11 overall, 5-10 Pacific-10 Conference), which had lost eight of nine. Maarty Leunen added 12 points. California had its chances after the Brooks free throws. On the ensuing trip down the court, Cal's Martin Smith clanked a 3-point attempt off the front of the rim. Teammate Dominic McGuire grabbed the rebound, but traveled on his way to the basket. Oregon, which missed 21 free throws during regulation of an overtime loss to No. 11 Washington two weeks ago, tacked on five more points from the line in the final half-minute to secure the victory. "Free throws are big in every game," Brooks said. "We've been working on it, shooting 50 everyday in practice. It paid off today." The win kept alive the Ducks' chances of making the Pac-10 tournament, as they moved into a three-way tie for seventh place in league with the Golden Bears (12-13, 5-10) and Washington State. The conference tournament only takes the top eight teams. "This was one more game to get us to the tournament," Leunen said. "This game was one we needed. It was a relief to get this one." Richard Midgley paced California with 13 points. It was his steal and assist that led to a game-tying dunk by Marquis Kately at the 2:50 mark, capping a 13-3 run by the Bears after Oregon had taken a 53-43 lead with 8:39 to play. But after each team failed to score on their ensuing possession, Brooks was sent to the free-throw line after drawing a foul from David Paris. Taylor was instrumental in snapping the Ducks offense out of their early game funk, scoring eight points in a 12-0 Oregon run that gave the Ducks a 25-17 lead with 4:36 left before halftime. Oregon led 32-24 at the break. "We wanted to go out there with a lot of confidence," Taylor said. "We have gotten nervous from the pressure in the past few games." The Ducks ended the first half making 9-of-12 attempts from the field. That was in stark contrast to the opening 10 minutes of the game when they made just two shots. Oregon ended the game shooting 50 percent. ^
